p._value:
openssl-s_time,
s_time - SSL/TLS performance timing program

_values: The
command implements a generic

client which connects to a remote
host using

It can request a page
from the server and includes the time to transfer the
payload data in its timing measurements. It measures the
number of connections within a given timeframe, the amount
of data transferred (if any), and calculates the average
time spent for one connection.

p._value:
This specifies the host and
optional port to connect to.

_values: This specifies the page to

from the server. A value of
’/’ gets the index.htm[l] page. If this
parameter is not specified, then

will only
perform the handshake to establish
connections but not transfer any payload data.

The certificate to use, if one
is requested by the server. The default is not to use a
certificate. The file is in
format.

The private key to use. If not
specified then the certificate file will be used. The file
is in
format.

p._value:
The verify depth to use. This
specifies the maximum length of the server certificate chain
and turns on server certificate verification. Currently the
verify operation continues after errors so all the problems
with a certificate chain can be seen. As a side effect the
connection will never fail due to a server certificate
verify failure.

_values:
Option which determines how the
subject or issuer names are displayed. The

argument can be a single option or multiple options
separated by commas. Alternatively the

switch may be used more than once to set multiple options.
See the
(1) manual page for details.

The directory to use for server
certificate verification. This directory must be in
"hash format", see

for more
information. These are also used when building the client
certificate chain.

p._value:
A file containing trusted
certificates to use during server authentication and to use
when attempting to build the client certificate chain.

_values: Do not load the trusted

certificates from the default file
location
Do not load the trusted

certificates from the default directory
location

Performs the timing test using
a new session

for each connection. If
neither
nor

are specified, they
are both on by default and executed in sequence.

Performs the timing test using
the same session

; this can be used as a
test that session caching is working. If neither
nor

are specified, they are both on by default
and executed in sequence.
This option disables the use of

version 3. By default the initial
handshake uses a method which should be compatible with all
servers and permit them to use
v3 or
as appropriate.

The timing
program is not as rich in options to turn protocols on and
off as the

(1) program and may not connect to
all servers. Unfortunately there are a lot of ancient and
broken servers in use which cannot handle this technique and
will fail to connect. Some servers only work if
is turned off with the
option.

p._value:
Note that this
option may not be available, depending on how OpenSSL was
built.

_values: There are several known bugs in
and

implementations.
Adding this option enables various workarounds.

This allows the TLSv1.2 and
below cipher list sent by the client to be modified. This
list will be combined with any TLSv1.3 ciphersuites that
have been configured. Although the server determines which
cipher suite is used it should take the first supported
cipher in the list sent by the client. See

(1)
for more information.

This allows the TLSv1.3
ciphersuites sent by the client to be modified. This list
will be combined with any TLSv1.2 and below ciphersuites
that have been configured. Although the server determines
which cipher suite is used it should take the first
supported cipher in the list sent by the client. See

(1) for more information. The format for this
list is a simple colon (":") separated list of
TLSv1.3 ciphersuite names.
Specifies how long (in seconds)

should establish connections and optionally
transfer payload data from a server. Server and client
performance and the link speed determine how many
connections
can establish.
can be used to measure the performance of an
connection. To connect to an
server and get the default page the command

p._value:
openssl s_time
-connect servername:443 -www / -CApath yourdir -CAfile
yourfile.pem -cipher commoncipher [-ssl3]

_values:
would typically
be used (https uses port 443). ’commoncipher’ is
a cipher to which both client and server can agree, see the
(1) command for details.

If the
handshake fails then there are several possible causes, if
it is nothing obvious like no client certificate then the
and

options can be tried in case
it is a buggy server. In particular you should play with
these options

submitting a bug report to an
OpenSSL mailing list.

A frequent
problem when attempting to get client certificates working
is that a web client complains it has no certificates or
gives an empty list to choose from. This is normally because
the server is not sending the clients certificate authority
in its "acceptable

list" when it
requests a certificate. By using
(1) the

list can be viewed and checked. However,
some servers only request client authentication after a
specific

is requested. To obtain the list
in this case it is necessary to use the
option of
(1) and send an
request for an appropriate page.

If a
certificate is specified on the command line using the

option it will not be used unless the server
specifically requests a client certificate. Therefore,
merely including a client certificate on the command line is
no guarantee that the certificate works.

Because this
program does not have all the options of the

(1) program to turn protocols on and off, you
may not be able to measure the performance of all protocols
with all servers.
The

option should really exit if the server
verification fails.
